subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law; having become a curse for us." (Galatians 3:13)
reflection: Scripture teaches us that there are two points of view from which we may regard Christ's death upon the cross. The one is the redemption of the cross: Christ dying for us as our complete deliverance from the curse of sin. (The other) The fellowship of the cross: Christ taking us up to die with Him and making us partakers of the fellowship of His death in our own experience. In our text we have three great unreachable thoughts: The law of God has pronounced a curse on all sin and on all that is sinful. Christ took our curse upon Himself ~ He became a curse and so destroyed its power. (and) In that cross we now have the everlasting redemption from sin and all its power. The cross reveals to us man's sin as under the curse, Christ becoming a curse and so overcoming it, and our full and everlasting deliverance from the curse. In these thoughts the lost and most hopeless sinner finds a sure ground of confidence and of hope.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I praise You for the redemption of the cross! Amen

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Have this in mind in you, which was also in Christ Jesus." (Philippians 2:5)
reflection: Here Paul tells us to be Christ minded: He emptied Himself; He took the form of a servant; He humbled Himself, even to death on the cross. It is this mind that was in Christ, the deep humility that gave up His life to the very death. That is the spirit that is to be in us. In this we shall prove and enjoy the blessed fellowship of His cross. Paul had said in (vs. 1) "If there is any comfort in Christ, " ~ The comforter was to come to reveal His presence in them ~ "If there is any fellowship of the spirit, " ~ If was in this power of the Spirit that they were to breathe the Spirit of the crucified Christ and manifest His disposition in the fellowship of the cross in their lives. It is no easy school and no hurried learning ~ this school of the cross. But it will lead to a deeper comprehension and a higher appreciation of the redemption of the cross through the personal experience of the fellowship of the cross.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, may I gain a higher appreciation of the redemption of the cross through the personal experience of the fellowship of the cross. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "I have been crucified with Christ; yet I live; and yet no longer I, but Christ liveth in me." (Galatians 2:20)
reflection: To often the thought of fellowship with Christ in His bearing the cross, has led to a vain attempt in our own power to follow Him and bear His image. but it is impossible until we first learn to know something of what it means to say, "I have been crucified with Christ." Let us try to understand this. When Adam died, all his descendants died with him and in him. In his sin in paradise and in the spiritual death into which he fell, we had a share; we died with him. The power of that sin and death, in which all his descendants share, works in every child of Adam every day. Now Christ came as the second Adam. In His death on the cross, all who believe in Him had a share. Each of us may say in truth, "I have been crucified with Christ." As the representative of His people, He took us up with Him on the cross, Yes you and me too. The life that He gives is the crucified life in which He entered heaven and was exalted to the throne, standing as a Lamb as it had been slain. The power of His death and life work in us, and as we hold fast to that truth that we have been crucified with Him, we now live no more but Christ liveth in us ~ in this power we will conquer sin. The life that we have received from Him is a life that has been made free from the power of sin.
prayer: Dear Lord, I long in every deed to be dead to all sin, so that the union of Your Son crucified and in fellowship of His cross can day by day it become my life. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "They that are in Christ Jesus have crucified the flesh with the passions and the lusts thereof." (Galatians 5:24)
reflection: Of the flesh Paul teaches us (Romans 7:18), in me, that is, in the flesh, dwelleth no good thing." and again (Romans 8:7), "The mind of the flesh is, enmity against God; for it is not subject to the law of God, neither indeed can it be." When Adam lost the Spirit of God, he became flesh, [Flesh] is the expression for the evil, corrupt nature that we inherit from Adam. [Of this flesh it is written] "Our old man was crucified with Him." (Romans 7:6) And Paul puts it more strongly when he says, "They that are in Christ Jesus have crucified the flesh." When the disciples heard and obeyed the call of Jesus to follow Him, they honestly meant to do so, but as Jesus later on taught them what that would imply, they were far from being ready to yield immediately. Yes even so those who are Christ's and have accepted Him as the Crucified One do not really understand what that includes. But by the act of surrender they have actually crucified the flesh and have consented to regard it as an accursed thing, nailed to the cross with Christ. Paul taught the Galatians, "Walk in the Spirit, and you shall not fulfill the lusts of the flesh." "As many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the children of God." And yes, only the Spirit, can guide us in living faith and fellowship with Christ as the flesh is kept in the place of crucifixion.
prayer: O Lord, how little I understood when I accepted you in faith that I crucified once for all the flesh with its passions and lusts! I ask You humbly, teach me to believe and so to live in You, the Crucified One, that I like Paul may always glory in the cross on which the world and the flesh are crucified. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Far be it from me to glory. save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through which the world hath been crucified unto me, and I unto the world." (Galatians 6:14)
reflection: Here Paul speaks of his only glory being that in Christ, he has in every deed been crucified to the world and entirely delivered from its power. When he said: "I have been crucified with Christ, " it was not only an inner spiritual truth, but an actual, practical experience in relation to the world and its temptations. Paul boasts that he lives as one crucified to the world, and that now the world as a powerless enemy was crucified to him. It was this that made him glory in the cross of Christ. O Christian friends, when the world crucified Christ, it crucified you with Him. When Christ overcame the world on the cross, he made you an overcome too. He calls you now, at whatever cost of self-denial, to regard the world in its hostility to God and His Kingdom as a crucified enemy over whom the cross can ever keep you conqueror. What a different relationship to the pleasures and attractions of the world the Christian has who by the Holy Spirit has learned to say: "I have been crucified with Christ; the crucified Christ liveth in me"!
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray that Your Holy Spirit may be revealed to us in all His power, teaching us what it means to "glory in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, through which the world has been crucified unto me." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "If you refuse to take up your cross and follow Me, you are not worthy of being Mine. If you cline to your life, you will lose it; but if you give it up for Me, you will find it. (Matthew 10:38-39)
reflection: To take up our cross and follow Jesus means to be willing to publicly identify with Him, to experience certain opposition, and to be willing to face suffering as well as possible death for His sake. Verse 39 gives us a positive and a negative statement of the same truth ~ Clinging to this life may cause us to forfeit the best from Christ in this world and the next. The more we love this life's rewards (leisure, power, popularity, financial security), the more we will discover how empty they are. The best way to enjoy life, is to loosen our greedy grasp on earthly rewards so that we can be free to follow Christ ~ In doing so we will inherit eternal life and began at once to experience the benefits of following Christ. Remember this call was not only to His disciple but to us also, so let us give up the self-life with its self-pleasing and self-exaltation and bear the cross in fellowship with Him, and we shall be made partakers of His victory.
prayer: Dear Lord I hear Your call to give up the self-life and bear the cross in fellowship with You so that I might be a partaker of Your victory, Lord help me to always be obedient to this call. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Then Jesus said to His disciples, "If any one wishes to come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow Me. (Matthew 16:24)
reflection: Christ had for the first time definitely announced that He would have to suffer much and be killed and be raised again."Peter rebuked Him, saying, 'Be it far from Thee, Lord: this shall never be unto Thee." Christ's answer was, "Get thee behind Me Satan." The spirit of Peter, seeking to turn Him away from the cross and its suffering, was nothing but Satan tempting Him to turn aside from the path which God had appointed as our way of salvation. Instead of denying himself, Peter denied his Lord: "I know not the man." When a man learns to obey Christ's command, he says of himself: "I know not the man." This is the secret of true discipleship, to bear the cross, to acknowledge the death sentence that has been passed on self, and to deny any right that self has to rule over us. The surrender for Christ sake to live for those around us is to be so complete, that self is never allowed to come down from the cross to which it has been crucified but is ever kept in the place of death.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, help me to hear Your voice, "Deny self, " I pray that by the grace of the Holy Spirit I may live crucified with Thee and that You will live in me as my Lord and Master. Amen.

verse: Then Jesus, beholding him, loved him, and said: "One thing thou lackest: go thy way, sell whatsoever thou hast, and come, take up the cross, and follow Me." (MK. 10:21)
reflection: Jesus showed genuine love for this man, even though He knew that the man might not follow Him. Love is able to give tough advise; it doesn't hedge on the truth. subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Jesus said: "the truth is, a kernel of wheat must be planted in the soil. Unless it dies it will be alone ~ a single seed. But its death will produce many new kernels ~ a plentiful harvest of new lives. Those who love their life in this world will lose it. Those who despise their life in this world will keep it for eternal life." (John 12:24-25) NLT
reflection: This is a beautiful picture of the necessary sacrifice of Jesus. Jesus had to die to pay the penalty for our sin, but also to show His power over death. His resurrection proves He has eternal life. Because Jesus is God, Jesus can give the same eternal life to all who believe in Him. BUT we must be so committed to living for Christ that we "despise" our lives in comparison ~ this does not mean that we long to die or that we are careless or destructive with the life God has given, but that we are willing to die if doing so will glorify Christ. Releasing control of our lives and transferring control to Christ will bring eternal life and genuine joy.
prayer: Dear Father in Heaven, How little this is understood! Help us believe that the law of the Spirit of Christ Jesus, can in every deed make His death and His life the daily experience of our souls. Amen.

prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, help me to be more yielding to your service, lead me in paths of righteousness for your name sake. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Father, into Thy hands I commit My Spirit." And having said this He gave up the ghost. (Luke 23:46)
reflection: Like David in (Psalm 31:5), Christ often committed His spirit into the hands of His Father for His daily life and need. But here is something new and very special. He gives up His spirit into the power of death, He gives up all control over it, to sink down into the darkness and death of the grave where He can neither think, nor pray, nor will. He surrenders Himself to the utmost into His Father's hands, trusting Him to care for Him in the dark and in due time to raise Him up again. If we have really died in Christ and are now in faith every day to carry about with us the death of our Lord Jesus, this is the very word we need. Just think once again what Christ meant when He said that we must hate and lose our life. And if we do this, we will find the answer in the mind which Christ died. Like Him we must cast ourselves upon the Father without knowing how the new life is to be attained; But as we in fellowship with Jesus say, "Father, into Thy hands I commit my spirit, " and depend simply and absolutely upon God to raise us up into the new life, There will be fulfilled in us the wonderful promise of God's Word concerning the greatness of His power in us who believe, according to the mighty power which He wrought in Christ when He raised Him from the dead.
prayer: Heavenly Father, as my spiritual life can only grow out of death, I too, pray, "Father, into Thy hands I commit my Spirit." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: We who died to sin, how shall we any longer live therein? (Romans 6:2)
reflection: In these words we have the deep spiritual truth that our death to sin in Christ delivers us from its power so that we no longer may or need to live in it. The secret of true and full holiness is by faith and in the power of the Holy Spirit to live in the consciousness 'I am dead to sin'. In expounding this truth Paul reminds his readers that we are baptized into the death of Christ. We were buried with Him through baptism into death. We became united with Him by the likeness of His death. Our "old man" was crucified with Him that the body of sin might be done away ~ rendered void and powerless. Take time and ask for the teaching of the Holy Spirit, quietly think about these words until the truth masters you: (I am indeed dead to sin in Christ Jesus). As we grow in the consciousness of our union with the crucified Christ, we shall experience that the power of His life in us has made us free from the power of sin.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, as I meditate on this truth: 'I am dead to sin in Christ Jesus, ' may I truly realize that His life in me sets me free from the power of sin. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by

In vs. 11 Paul pleads with his readers "Even so reckon yourselves to be dead to sin, but alive to God in Christ Jesus." Now it is true that this is a truth that our minds can not master and appropriate, but it is a reality which the Holy Spirit will reveal to us. By His power we can accept our death with Christ on the cross as the power of our daily life.
prayer: Heavenly Father help me accept Your Divine assurance that I shall live with Christ. Amen.

verse: We always carry around in our body the death of Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be revealed in our body. So then, death is at work in us, but life is at work in you. (2 Corinthians 4:10, 12)
reflection: We often speak of our abiding in Christ. but we forget that, that means the abiding in a crucified Christ. Many believers appear to think that when once they have claimed Christ's death in the fellowship of the cross and have counted themselves as crucified with Him, that they may now consider it as past and done with. They do not understand that it is in the crucified Christ and in the fellowship of His death that they are to abide daily and unceasingly. Let us not forget that the fellowship of the cross is to be the life of a daily experience, the self-emptying of our Lord, His taking the form of a servant, His humbling Himself and becoming obedient unto death, even the death of the cross. This mind that was in Christ is to be the disposition that marks our daily life.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, help me to learn the lesson that the abiding in Christ for which I have so often prayed and striven for is nothing less than the abiding of the crucified in me and I in Him. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: How much more, then, will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered Himself unblemished to God, cleanse our consciences from acts that lead to death, so that we may serve the living God. (Hebrews 9:14)
reflection: Yes there still are those who even though they know Christ, are still working hard to make themselves good enough for God. BUT rules and rituals have never cleansed people's hearts. ONLY by Jesus' blood: (1) we have our conscience cleansed, (2) we are freed from death's sting and can live to serve God, (3) we are freed from sin's power. If you are one of many who are still carrying a load of guilt because you are finding that you can't be good enough for God, take another look at Jesus' death and what it means for you. Christ can heal your conscience and deliver you from the frustration of trying to earn God's favor.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, I pray that You would continually remind me and others like me, we have been crucified with Christ, in Him we have died to sin. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Therefore, brothers, since we have confidence to enter the Most Holy Place by the blood of Jesus ~ by a new and living way opened for us through the curtain, that is, His body (Hebrews 10:19-20)
reflection: In the temple there was a veil between the holy place and the most holy. At the altar in the court the blood of the sacrifice was sprinkled for the forgiveness of sins. That gave the priests entrance into the holy place to offer God the incense as part of a holy worship. But into the Most Holy, behind the veil, the High Priest alone might enter once a year. That veil was the type of sinful nature; even though it had received the forgiveness of sin, full access and fellowship with God was impossible. When Christ died, the veil was rent. Christ dedicated a new and living way to God through the rent veil of His flesh. This new way, by which we now can enter into the holiest of all, ever passes through the rent veil of the flesh. Every believer "has crucified the flesh with the passions and the lusts thereof." (Galatians 5:24)
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, help us to praise Thee that the Holy Spirit ever dwells in us to keep the flesh in its place of crucifixion and condemnation and to give us the abiding victory over all temptation. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Let us run with patience the race that is set before us, looking unto Jesus, the Author and Perfecter of our faith, who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame. (Hebrews 12:1b-2) R. V.
reflection: To be successful at any race the eye and the heart need to be set upon the goal and the prize. Christians are called to keep their eyes fix upon Jesus. In our life we are to be led by the Spirit, this will lead to the throne (the goal) and the glory of God. (the prize) This is the new way which He opened for us through the veil of the flesh. It is as we study that we will realize that it was for His bearing the cross that God so highly exalted Him, so let us walk in His footsteps bearing our cross after Him with the flesh condemned and crucified. As believers let us awake to His blessed truth and run the race always looking to the crucified Jesus, and we will receive power to win for Christ the souls He has purchased on the cross.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, Help us to fix our eyes on Jesus enduring the cross as the one object of our desire. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Under the system of the Jewish laws, the high priest brought the blood of animals into the Holy Place as a sacrifice for sin, but the bodies of the animals were burned outside the camp. So also Jesus suffered and died outside the city gates in order to make His people holy by shedding His blood. So let us go out to Him outside the camp and bear the disgrace He bore. (Hebrews 13:11-13)
reflection: There are many Christians who love to hear of the boldness with which we can enter into the Holy Place through His blood, who yet have little desire for the fellowship of His reproach and are unwilling to separate themselves from the world with the same boldness with which they think to enter the sanctuary. Christians suffer inconceivable loss when they think of entering into the Holy Place in faith and prayer and then feel themselves free to enjoy the friendship of the world so long as they do nothing actually sinful. But the Word of God has said: "Know ye not that the friendship of the world is enmity against God?" "Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world; if any man loves the world, the love of the Father is not in Him." "Be not conformed to this world." To be a follower of Christ means to be like Him in His love of the cross and His will to sacrifice self that the Father may be glorified and others may be saved.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, teach me what it means that I am called to follow You outside the camp, bearing Your reproach, and so to bear witness to Your holy redeeming love. Let the Spirit and the love that was in You be in me too, that I may at any cost seek to win the souls for whom You have died. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: He Himself bore our sins in His body on the tree, so that we might die to sins and live for righteousness; by His wounds you have been healed. (1 Peter 2:24)
reflection: We need to remember daily what it cost Jesus to bear the cost of the cross. We merely have to remember some of His last words, like when He cried ~ "Now is my soul troubled, and what shall I say? Father, save Me from this hour. But for this cause came I unto this hour." Let us not imagine that the fellowship of the cross of which Peter speaks here, "That we, having died to sins, might live unto righteousness, " is easily understood or experienced. It means that we have to be willing to allow the Holy Spirit to teach us what it is to be identified with Christ in His cross. It means that we will have to realize by faith how actually we shared with Christ in His death and now, as He lives in us, must live in an unceasing fellowship with Him, the Crucified One. This costs self-sacrifice; it costs earnest prayer; it costs a wholehearted surrender to God and His will and the cross of Jesus; it costs living in Christ and unceasing fellowship with Him.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Father, help me to discover fully what it means to live day by day the secret of living a life in and for You. Amen.
